vehicles.name: Sopwith Camel
vehicles.desc: The most successful fighter of the Great War — and the most dangerous to its own pilots. The rotary engine's torque makes her turn like lightning to the right and like a drunk to the left. She killed more enemy aircraft than any other Allied type, and more trainee pilots than the Germans did.
vehicles.notes: The Camel's torque is a mechanical feature: +1 Handling on right turns, -1 on left. This asymmetry makes dogfights tactical rather than abstract. Experienced pilots exploit it; novices die learning. Perfect for campaigns where pilot skill matters as much as the machine.

vehicles.name: Fokker Dr.I
vehicles.desc: Three wings, a rotary engine, and the ability to climb faster than anything else in the sky. The Red Baron's mount. She's slow in level flight but in a turning, climbing dogfight she's nearly untouchable. Every Allied pilot who met one remembered the experience — if they survived it.
vehicles.notes: The Dr.I's advantage is climb rate and turn radius, not speed. She loses in a straight chase but wins any turning fight. Use her for named aces — the Dr.I is a character aircraft, not a mass-production type. Give the pilot a name, a reputation, and a kill count.

vehicles.name: SPAD XIII
vehicles.desc: France's answer to the Fokker. Fast, strong, and capable of diving at speeds that would tear a Camel apart. She's heavier than the British fighters, which means she can't turn as tightly, but she makes up for it by going through the enemy formation like a cannonball.
vehicles.notes: The SPAD is your energy fighter — she dives fast, fires, and climbs away. She doesn't turn-fight; she boom-and-zooms. Use her for players who prefer speed over agility. The contrast with the Camel creates interesting tactical choices within a flight.

vehicles.name: Albatros D.III
vehicles.desc: The shark of 1917. Sleek, fast, and carrying twin synchronised Spandaus that fire through the propeller arc. The Albatros gave Germany air superiority during Bloody April, when RFC pilots lasted an average of eleven days before being killed.
vehicles.notes: The Albatros is your standard German opposition for 1917 campaigns. She's well-balanced — fast enough to catch, tough enough to survive a burst, and armed well enough to kill in one pass. Use her in formations of four to six for historically accurate Jasta encounters.

vehicles.name: SE.5a
vehicles.desc: The gentleman's fighter. Stable, fast, and fitted with both a synchronised Vickers and a wing-mounted Lewis gun. She doesn't have the Camel's vicious agility, but she's much easier to fly and much harder to kill. Most of the top British aces finished the war in SE.5as.
vehicles.notes: The SE.5a is your reliable alternative to the Camel. She's forgiving for new players — no torque quirks, good speed, decent armament. The wing-mounted Lewis can be pulled down on a Foster mount to fire upward, which is devastating against enemies above.

vehicles.name: Nieuport 17
vehicles.desc: A tiny French sesquiplane — one and a half wings — that could out-climb anything in 1916. She's light, nimble, and armed with a single Lewis gun on the upper wing. The Nieuport was the fighter that proved air combat was more than a novelty.
vehicles.notes: The Nieuport is your early-war fighter. She's outclassed by 1918 but in 1916-17 she's competitive. Use her for campaigns that start early in the war, letting the players feel the technology evolve as better aircraft arrive. The single gun means every burst counts.

vehicles.name: Zeppelin L-33
vehicles.desc: Six hundred feet of hydrogen, duralumin, and terror. She cruises at fifteen thousand feet — above the ceiling of most fighters — and drops bombs on cities that have never been attacked from the air before. London in 1915 had no air defence. The Zeppelins came and went as they pleased.
vehicles.notes: The Zeppelin is your strategic threat and your Gargantuan target. She's enormous, slow, and filled with hydrogen — one incendiary round and she's a torch. But she flies higher than most fighters can reach. Use her for interception missions where the challenge is getting to altitude before she drops her bombs.

vehicles.name: Gotha G.V
vehicles.desc: Germany's heavy bomber. Twin engines, a three-man crew, and a bomb load that terrorised London after the Zeppelins proved too vulnerable. She flies in formation, she has defensive gunners covering every angle, and shooting one down requires getting through a crossfire of machine guns.
vehicles.notes: The Gotha is your bomber interception scenario. A formation of six Gothas is a formidable defensive problem — each gunner covers the others. The players need to break the formation, isolate individual bombers, and attack from blind spots. Run it as a tactical puzzle, not a simple dogfight.

vehicles.name: RE.8
vehicles.desc: The observation aircraft that every infantry officer wanted overhead and every pilot dreaded flying. Slow, poorly armed, and expected to loiter over the trenches while the enemy fighters queue up to kill her. The observer in the back seat has a Lewis gun and a prayer.
vehicles.notes: The RE.8 is your escort mission. She can't run, she can't fight effectively, and she has to stay over the target area to complete her observation. The players in their fighters protect her while German scouts try to shoot her down. If she goes down, the artillery is blind.

vehicles.name: Bristol F.2B
vehicles.desc: The two-seat fighter that changed the rules. Most two-seaters were vulnerable targets — the Bristol Fighter flew like a single-seater and had a rear gunner who made attacking from behind suicidal. Pilots who treated her as a fighter rather than an observation platform dominated the sky.
vehicles.notes: The Bristol Fighter is your versatile player aircraft. She dogfights like a scout, the rear gunner covers the tail, and she can do reconnaissance on the side. Two player characters per aircraft — pilot and observer — with complementary roles. The rear gun makes tail attacks genuinely dangerous for the enemy.
